questions.question: Nasopharyngeal AngiofibromaWhat type of lesion is angiofibroma?

A patient presented with difficulty in breathing and swallowing. On examination, a painlessnasopharyngeal mass was noted. Angiofibroma was suspected. Which of the followingstatements is false about this condition?
questions.explanation: The image shows a nasopharyngeal mass suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma(JNA), which is causing difficulty in breathing and swallowing. It is more common in males.The tumor is predominantly seen in adolescent males in the second decade of life. It is thought tobe testosterone dependent. Patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in thenasopharynx which is activated to form angiofibroma when male sex hormones appear.A biopsy is contraindicated due to the risk of severe bleeding. The vessels lack contractilecomponents and hence bleeding cannot be controlled with adrenaline.

questions.question: (b)496A 16-year-old boy presents to you with complaints of nasal obstruction and frequent nosebleeds. CT scan shows Holman-Miller sign. You suspect a benign tumour of the nasopharynx.What is its most common site of origin?

options.C: Anterior wall of the sphenoid bone

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive ofthe diagnosis of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). It most commonly arises from thesphenopalatine foramen.From here the tumour grows into the:• Nasal cavity•Nasopharynx.Pterygopalatine fossa•Pterygomaxillary fossa• Infratemporal fossaGiven below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus-Holman-Miller sign.501

questions.question: Which of the following features will not be seen in a patient with nasopharyngealangiofibroma?
questions.explanation: Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma presents with rhinolalia clausa (hyponasal speech), not rhinolaliaaperta (hypernasal speech).The patients present with progressive nasal obstruction and hyponasal speech due to mass in thepostnasal space. Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis is the most common presentation.The patients may be markedly anemic due to repeated blood loss.Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion occur due to obstruction of the eustachiantube.It can spread to the orbit giving rise to proptosis and broadening of the nasal bridge, giving rise tofrog face deformity. Other features include swelling of the cheek and cranial nerve palsies (II, III,IV, and VI).

questions.question: A mother brought her 16-year-old boy with a unilateral profuse nosebleed. After successfulcontrol of bleeding, a CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of juvenile angiofibroma. What is thereason for it to cause excessive bleeding?
questions.explanation: Angiofibroma is made of vascular and fibrous tissues. Vessels of angiofibroma lack contractilecomponents, they are just endothelium-lined spaces with no elastic or muscle coat.This accounts for severe bleeding as the vessels lose the ability to contract. Hence the bleedingcannot be controlled by the application of adrenaline. Therefore, the biopsy is contraindicated.

questions.question: Which of the following deformity is likely to be seen in a patient with juvenile nasopharyngealangiofibroma?
questions.explanation: Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma when spreads to the orbit, lead to proptosis and broadening of thenasal bridge, giving rise to frog-face deformity.502Option A: Gorilla-like facies are seen in acromegaly.Option C: Bird-like facies are seen in the Pierre-Robin sequence.Option D: Lion-like facies are seen in Paget's disease of bone when craniofacial bones areinvolved.

questions.question: A teenage boy presents to you with recurrent epistaxis and hearing loss. On examination, hehas a frog-face deformity and conductive hearing loss. Which of the following is theinvestigation of choice to diagnose the condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Investigation of choiceto diagnose this condition is contrast enhancement CT scan (CECT).MRI scan can be used complementary to CT to see soft tissue extensions of the tumor.Carotid angiography shows the extent of the tumor, its vascularity, and feeding vessels whichmostly come from the external carotid system. Embolization of vessels can be done at this time todecrease bleeding at operation.A biopsy is contraindicated in this condition as it can lead to massive hemorrhage.

questions.question: In a suspected case of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, CECT is performed. Which of thefollowing signs will help diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation: Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus in CECT of head and neck is calledan antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, which is pathognomonic for angiofibroma.Option A: Tram track sign is used to differentiate optic nerve sheath meningiomas from opticgliomas. Optic nerve sheath meningiomas will show a positive tram-track sign.Option C: Stripe sign/ tigroid pattern represents a specific pattern of demyelination, with sparingof perivascular white matter. It is seen in metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD).503Option D: Eye-of-a-tiger sign represents marked low signal intensity of the globi pallidi on T2WMRI images.

questions.question: Imaging of a patient with recurrent epistaxis shows the following finding. Which of thefollowing statements is false about his condition?498

options.B: Tumor does not have a capsule
options.C: Digital palpation should never be done in OPD

questions.explanation: The image shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, which is calledan antral sign or Holman-Miller sign. It is pathognomonic for angiofibroma. Recurrence ofjuvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is common.It is a rare tumor but is the commonest benign tumor of the nasopharynx. It commonly arisesfrom the sphenopalatine foramen. It does not have a capsule.Digital palpation should never be done until at the time of operation, as it can lead to severehemorrhage.

questions.question: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has minimally spread into the sphenoid sinuswith no lateral extension. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?
questions.explanation: The mass has spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension, so it's Stage 1B accordingto the Radkowski classification.Multiple classification systems exist for the staging of juvenile nasal angiofibroma, of which themost commonly used ones are the Fisch and Radkowski classification systems:Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Radkowski, et al):Fisch staging system of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumorseen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasionalmortality.Note: The Fisch system is considered to be the more robust and practical of the two.Stag SpreadeIALimited to the nose and/or nasopharyngeal vaultIBExtension into ≥ 1 sinusIIAMinimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossaIIBFull occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with or without erIICosion of orbital bonesInfratemporal fossa with orwithout cheek or posterior topterygoid plates504StagSpreadIIIAIIIBErosion of skull base-minima1 intracranialErosion of skull base-extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinusType123B:Tumour invading theinfratemporal fossaororbital regionwithintracranialextradural(parasellar) involvementDetailsTumourlimited to the nasopharyngeal cavity; bonedestruction negligibleor limited to the sphenopalatine foramenTumourinvading the pterygopalatine fossaor the maxillary,ethmoid, or sphenoidsinus with bone destructionA:Tumour invading theinfratemporal fossaororbital regionwithoutintracranial involvement4B:Intracranialintraduraltumorwithinfiltration of the cavernous sinus, pituitary fossa, oroptic chiasmA:Intracranialintraduraltumorwithoutinfiltration of the cavernous sinus, pituitary fossa,or optic chiasm

questions.question: A young boy with a history of frequent nosebleeds and unilateral nasal blockage. CT scanshows Holman- Miller sign. It also shows the presence of a mass in the nasopharynx thatextends into and occupies the pterygopalatine fossa. What is the best treatment for thispatient?
questions.explanation: The clinical picture suggests that of stage IIB nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Surgery is themainstay of treatment of angiofibroma for stage I and stage II tumors.Radiotherapy is indicated in stage III where there is an intracranial extension or when the tumoris unresectable.Chemotherapy can be used for very aggressive resurrect tumors and residual lesions.Stages of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:Hormonal therapy was used in the past, but not anymore.505StagSpreadeIALimited to the nose and/or nasopharyngeal vaultIBExtension into ≥ 1 sinusIIAMinimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossaIIBFull occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with or without erIICIIIAosion of orbital bonesInfratemporal fossa with orwithout cheek or posterior topterygoid platesErosion of skull base-minima1 intracranialIIIBErosion of skull base-extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

questions.question: Radiotherapy is indicated when the spread of angiofibroma extends to which site?
questions.explanation: Radiotherapy is used for intracranial extension of disease when tumour derives its blood supplyfrom the internal carotid system. Recurrent angiofibromas have also been treated byradiotherapy.506
